questions.text: Which structure contributes to the virulence of Neisseria gonorrhoeae by preventing phagocytosis and assisting in attachment to host cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Pili (Fimbriae)
Explanation:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae uses pili for adhesion to mucosal surfaces and evasion of immune defences through antigenic variation. Although it lacks a true capsule, the pili are critical for pathogenesis and are subject to phase and antigenic variation, which aids immune evasion.

questions.text: An obligate aerobe will exhibit which of the following features during thioglycolate broth incubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Growth only at the top
Explanation:
Obligate aerobes require oxygen for survival and produce energy via oxidative phosphorylation. In thioglycolate broth, oxygen is most abundant at the surface, so obligate aerobes grow only at the top layer. Facultative anaerobes grow throughout but better at the top, while obligate anaerobes grow at the bottom.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MacConkey agar
Explanation:
MacConkey agar is selective and differential. It inhibits Gram-positive bacteria via bile salts and crystal violet and differentiates lactose fermenters (pink colonies) from non-fermenters. It’s widely used for enteric pathogens like E. coli, Salmonella, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following is a chemically defined synthetic medium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Minimal salt agar
Explanation:
A synthetic or chemically defined medium contains known quantities of all ingredients. Minimal salt agar contains salts, glucose, and essential nutrients and is used for genetic studies and identifying mutants like auxotroph.

questions.text: Which method is best for determining bacterial population growth over time in a liquid culture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Turbidimetry (optical density)
Explanation:
Turbidimetry uses a spectrophotometer to measure optical density (OD), giving a rapid estimate of bacterial mass. Although it includes both live and dead cells, it's ideal for monitoring real time growth kinetics in broth cultures, especially during the log phase.

questions.text: Which genetic mechanism allows Streptococcus pneumoniae to acquire a capsule and evade immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Transformation
Explanation:
Transformation is uptake of naked DNA from the environment. S. pneumoniae can acquire genes encoding a capsule via transformation, allowing antigenic variation and evasion of host immune responses.

questions.text: Which bacterial toxin increases intracellular cyclic AMP by activating adenylate cyclase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cholera toxin
Explanation:
Cholera toxin (an AB toxin) catalyses ADP ribosylation of Gs protein, stimulating adenylate cyclase, leading to ↑cAMP in intestinal epithelial cells. This results in Cl⁻ secretion and profuse watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is most appropriate to visualize Mycobacterium leprae in tissue samples?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ziehl Neelsen stain
Explanation:
Mycobacterium leprae is acid fast due to mycolic acid in its cell wall. Ziehl Neelsen (carbol fuchsin) stain is used to identify acid fast bacilli. Fite Faraco is a modified version used in lepra bacilli from biopsy samples.

questions.text: Which culture method is best for isolating and identifying obligate intracellular bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tissue culture
Explanation:
Obligate intracellular organisms (e.g., Chlamydia, Rickettsia) require living host cells for replication. Thus, tissue culture systems are essential for their growth and visualization, often observed using inclusion bodies or immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Which of the following bacterial toxins acts via inhibition of the 60S ribosomal subunit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Shiga toxin
Explanation:
Shiga toxin from Shigella dysenteriae (and Shiga like toxin from EHEC) cleaves the 60S ribosomal subunit, halting protein synthesis and causing cell death. It also contributes to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

questions.text: A 1 µm organism with no cell wall, resistant to βlactams, appears as a "fried egg" colony on PPLO agar. Which stain is least useful?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gram stain
Explanation:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall and thus cannot be Gram stained. Diene’s stain and DNA specific stains are used instead. Giemsa stain may also highlight the organism in infected tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following is a differential medium that distinguishes between lactose fermenters and no fermenters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MacConkey agar
Explanation:
MacConkey agar contains lactose and neutral red. Lactose fermenters (e.g., E. coli) appear pink, while no fermenters (e.g., Salmonella, Shigella) remain colorless. It is both selective (for Gram negatives) and differential.

questions.text: Which of the following microscopes provides the highest magnification and resolution?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Transmission electron microscope (TEM)
Explanation:
TEM provides magnifications up to 1 million × and reveals fine internal ultrastructural details (e.g., ribosomes, viral particles). It uses a beam of electrons rather than light, and the sample must be sectioned ultrathin.

questions.text: Which of the following bacterial genetic elements is capable of integrating into the host chromosome and later excising itself to enter a lytic cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prophage
Explanation:
A prophage is a bacteriophage genome integrated into the host bacterium’s DNA during the lysogenic cycle. Under certain stimuli (like UV light), it can excise and enter the lytic cycle, producing new virions and lysing the host.

questions.text: Which staining technique is best used to demonstrate the presence of bacterial capsules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

India ink stain

Explanation:
India ink is a negative stain used to visualize capsules, especially in Cryptococcus neoformans. The capsule appears as a clear halo against the dark background. Gram stain doesn’t highlight capsules well.

questions.text: A Gram- positive rod forms black colonies with a ground glass appearance on PEMBA medium. The organism is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bacillus cereus
Explanation:
PEMBA (Polymyxin Egg Yolk Mannitol Bromothymol Blue Agar) is selective for B. cereus, which forms bluish-black colonies with lecithinase positivity (halo around colonies). It's used to detect food poisoning outbreaks.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is found only in Gram-negative bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Outer membrane
Explanation:
Only Gram-negative bacteria possess an outer membrane rich in lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Teichoic and lipoteichoic acids are unique to Gram-positive organisms.

questions.text: The best method to sterilize heat-sensitive liquids like vaccines and serum is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Filtration
Explanation:
Membrane filtration (0.22 µm pores) is used to sterilize heat labile solutions such as vaccines and sera without affecting their biological activity.

questions.text: A typical gene transfer that requires bacteriophage as a vector is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transduction
Explanation:
Transduction is gene transfer via bacteriophages, which accidentally package host DNA and deliver it to other bacteria — can be generalized or specialized.

questions.text: The phase where bacterial death equals growth, with nutrient depletion and toxic accumulation, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Stationary phase
Explanation:
In the stationary phase, nutrients are depleted, waste accumulates, and cell division rate equals death rate. It’s associated with spore formation in some species (e.g., Bacillus, Clostridium).

questions.text: Which antibody is primarily involved in mucosal immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B). 

IgA
Explanation:
IgA, especially in its secretory dimeric form, is the predominant immunoglobulin in mucosal surfaces (GI, respiratory, genitourinary tracts). It neutralizes pathogens at entry points and is resistant to proteolytic degradation. It's abundant in saliva, tears, and breast milk.

questions.text: The complement pathway that is activated by antigen-antibody complexes is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Classical pathway
Explanation:
The classical pathway of complement is triggered by IgG or IgM bound to antigen, leading to C1 activation. This eventually generates C3 convertase and downstream effects like opsonization, chemotaxis, and cell lysis. The alternative and lectin pathways are antibody independent.

questions.text: Which cytokine is primarily responsible for class switching to IgE production in allergic reactions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 IL4
Explanation:
IL4, secreted by Th2 cells, is crucial for class switching to IgE, a key mediator of type I hypersensitivity. IL4 also promotes B cell activation and suppresses Th1 differentiation.

questions.text: Which immune cell type is central to the delayed type of hypersensitivity (DTH) response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CD4+ Th1 lymphocytes
Explanation:
Th1 subtype of CD4+ T cells mediate Type IV hypersensitivity, including DTH responses. Upon re-exposure to antigen, they release IFN-γ and TNFα, activating macrophages and causing tissue inflammation (e.g., TB skin test, contact dermatitis).

questions.text: In agglutination reactions, latex agglutination tests are used to detect:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Soluble antigens or antibodies
Explanation:
Latex agglutination involves latex beads coated with antibodies (or antigens) that agglutinate in the presence of target antigen or antibody. It’s rapid, sensitive, and used for detecting CRP, ASO, and bacterial antigens in CSF.

questions.text: Which immune cells are primarily involved in antibody dependent cell mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 NK cells
Explanation:
NK cells play a key role in ADCC, where they bind to the Fc region of IgG coating target cells. Upon binding, NK cells release perforin and granzymes, leading to apoptosis of the target. ADCC is also seen with eosinophils in helminth infections (IgE mediated).

questions.text: The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules present peptides to which type of cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cytotoxic T cells  
Explanation: 
MHC class I molecules present endogenously synthesized peptides to cytotoxic T cells (CD8+ T cells).

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Anaphylaxis  
Explanation: 
Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate reactions mediated by IgE antibodies, such as anaphylaxis and allergies.

questions.text: Which cell surface marker is characteristic of helper T cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CD4  
Explanation: 
CD4 is a glycoprotein found on the surface of helper T cells, which is crucial for their role in immune signalling.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity is mediated by immune complexes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type III  
Explanation: 
Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complexes that trigger inflammation and tissue damage.

questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
    
 Type IV  
Explanation: 
Contact dermatitis is a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which is a delayed type of reaction mediated by T cells.

questions.text: Which type of immunity is provided by a vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Artificial active immunity
Explanation: 
Vaccination induces artificial active immunity by exposing the immune system to an antigen without causing disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of the adaptive immune response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
    
Specificity for antigens  
Explanation: 
The adaptive immune response is highly specific to particular antigens and has memory for faster response upon re-exposure.

questions.text: What is the primary role of dendritic cells in the immune system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)  

Presenting antigens to T cells  
Explanation: 
Dendritic cells are professional antigen presenting cells that process and present antigens to T cells to initiate an immune response.

questions.text: Which molecule is crucial for antigen recognition by T cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TCR  
Explanation: 
The T cell receptor (TCR) is essential for recognizing antigens presented by MHC molecules on antigen presenting cells.

questions.text: Which molecule is recognized by helper T cells on antigen presenting cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
     
MHC II  
Explanation: 
Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) recognize antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen presenting cells.

questions.text: Which cells are responsible for the secondary immune response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
    
Memory B cells  
Explanation: 
Memory B cells are responsible for the rapid and robust response upon re exposure to an antigen.

questions.text: Which bacterial structure contributes to antigenic shift and drug resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Pili
Explanation:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae undergoes antigenic variation in pili, helping evade immune detection and contributing to persistent infections. These pili also facilitate adherence and play a role in horizontal gene transfer, influencing resistance.

questions.text: The primary difference between simple and differential staining is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Number of dyes used
Explanation:
Simple stains use a single dye to visualize morphology. Differential stains (e.g., Gram, acid-fast) use multiple dyes to distinguish between types of bacteria based on structure/composition.

choices.text: Chocolate agar with X and V factors

questions.text: Which of the following media is enriched and used to isolate Haemophilus influenzae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chocolate agar with X and V factors
Explanation:
H. influenzae requires X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors. These are provided by chocolate agar, where RBCs are lysed to release these nutrients.

questions.text: The "string test" is used in identification of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vibrio cholerae
Explanation:
V. cholerae forms a mucoid string when mixed with sodium deoxycholate — positive “string test”. It helps differentiate it from other Gram-negative bacilli.

questions.text: Clostridium botulinum causes flaccid paralysis by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blocking acetylcholine release
Explanation:
Botulinum toxin inhibits acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions, leading to flaccid paralysis. It’s used therapeutically in small doses (Botox).

questions.text: A bacterial toxin that causes ADP-ribosylation of G-proteins, leading to increased cAMP and leucocytosis, is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pertussis toxin
Explanation:
Pertussis toxin modifies the Gi protein, preventing inhibition of adenylate cyclase → ↑cAMP → leucocytosis and immune evasion. It also contributes to the classic paroxysmal cough in whooping cough.

questions.text: The bacteria causing diphtheria can be identified by which of the following special stains?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Albert stain
Explanation:
Albert stain is used to detect metachromatic granules (volutin granules) in Corynebacterium diphtheriae. These granules are rich in polyphosphates and appear bluish-black, aiding diagnosis.

choices.text: Bacterium gaining new traits due to integrated phage DNA

questions.text: The term "lysogenic conversion" refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bacterium gaining new traits due to integrated phage DNA
Explanation:
Lysogenic conversion occurs when a temperate phage integrates into the host genome and expresses new genes, like toxin genes (e.g., diphtheria toxin, cholera toxin). This changes the phenotype of the bacterium.

questions.text: The toxin responsible for gas gangrene has which principal enzymatic activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lecithinase
Explanation:
Clostridium perfringens produces alpha toxin (lecithinase C), which hydrolyzes lecithin in cell membranes, leading to tissue necrosis, hemolysis, and gas gangrene.

questions.text: Which of the following features is shared by both Shigella and Salmonella, despite being different genera?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Invasion of intestinal mucosa
Explanation:
Both Shigella and Salmonella invade the intestinal epithelium. However, Shigella is non-motile and does not produce H₂S, whereas Salmonella is motile and H₂S positive. Both are non-lactose fermenters.

questions.text: A bacterial sample shows green metallic sheen colonies on EMB agar. What is the most likely identification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Escherichia coli
Explanation:
Eosin Methylene Blue (EMB) agar is both selective and differential. Strong lactose fermenters like E. coli produce a green metallic sheen, distinguishing them from weaker fermenters like Enterobacter.

choices.text: Capsule absorbs dye and appears red
Capsule excludes dye, appearing as a halo
Dye reacts with mucopolysaccharides in capsule

questions.text: In negative staining, such as with India ink, what is the principle behind capsule visualization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Capsule excludes dye, appearing as a halo
Explanation:
Negative staining uses dyes like India ink, which the capsule excludes, creating a clear halo around the dark background. The organism itself may take up a counterstain.

questions.text: In bacterial protein synthesis, what is the target of macrolide antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

50S ribosomal subunit
Explanation:
Macrolides (e.g., erythromycin) bind to the 50S subunit, inhibiting translocation during protein elongation. Tetracyclines target 30S; fluoroquinolones inhibit DNA gyrase (topoisomerase II).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child develops scalded skin syndrome. Microscopy shown in the image. Which toxin is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
Exfoliative toxins A and B from S. aureus cleave desmoglein-1, leading to scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with a prosthetic valve develops infective endocarditis. The culture grows coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. Which is the most important virulence factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
Biofilm formation on prosthetic devices is critical for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus pathogenesis.

questions.text: Bacitracin sensitivity in culture helps differentiate which of the following streptococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
S. pyogenes (Group A) is bacitracin sensitive, unlike S. agalactiae (Group B).

questions.text: A diabetic patient with trauma to the leg presents with crepitus, pain, and blackish discoloration. Gram stain shows large Gram-positive rods. Which toxin is responsible for tissue necrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: 
Clostridium perfringens alpha toxin (lecithinase) is the primary virulence factor in gas gangrene.

questions.text: A neonate develops meningitis. Gram stain reveals Gram-positive rods with tumbling motility. The pathogen is also CAMP test positive. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: 
Listeria is CAMP positive, causes neonatal meningitis, and shows tumbling motility.

questions.text: In diphtheria, which medium helps in demonstrating metachromatic granules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
Loeffler’s medium enhances granule production in Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with poor dental hygiene develops multiple discharging sinuses on the jaw. Culture shows filamentous, branching Gram-positive rods. Which is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: 
Actinomyces israelii causes cervicofacial actinomycosis, characterized by sulphur granules in sinuses.

questions.text: A patient with chronic lung disease shows acid-fast, branching filamentous bacteria on Ziehl-Neelsen stain. What is the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
Nocardia is weakly acid-fast and causes pulmonary infections resembling TB.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a painless black eschar on the arm. Which is the likely agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
B. anthracis causes cutaneous anthrax with a characteristic painless black eschar.

questions.text: A hospital outbreak of pseudomembranous colitis is traced to antibiotic use. What is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
Diagnosis of Clostridium difficile colitis requires detection of toxin A/B in stool.

questions.text: Which bacterial genus is best identified by reverse CAMP test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
C. perfringens shows positive reverse CAMP test with enhanced hemolysis.

questions.text: A newborn with poor feeding and opisthotonus posture is diagnosed with neonatal tetanus. Which toxin is responsible for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Explanation: 
Tetanospasmin inhibits release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, causing spastic paralysis.

questions.text: In Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which structure contributes to virulence and helps in evading phagocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation: 
Cord factor (trehalose di-mycolate) is toxic and prevents phagolysosome fusion.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can be grown in cold enrichment culture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
Listeria can grow at 4°C, which helps in selective enrichment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with strawberry tongue, pharyngitis, and sandpaper rash. Which serotype is associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation: 
S. pyogenes (Group A) causes scarlet fever.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fever, malaise, and an expanding bull’s-eye rash on his leg. He recently returned from a hiking trip. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by Ixodes tick bites, causes Lyme disease. The hallmark is erythema migrans—an expanding, annular rash with central clearing. Early diagnosis and treatment with doxycycline prevent systemic complications such as arthritis and carditis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with cervicitis and mucopurulent vaginal discharge. NAAT of endocervical swab is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis. Which serovars are typically associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Explanation:
Serovars D–K of Chlamydia trachomatis causes urogenital infections, neonatal conjunctivitis, and pneumonia. Serovars A–C cause trachoma, and L1–L3 are responsible for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: A man develops painful inguinal buboes and genital ulcers. Serology confirms lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:
LGV, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1–L3, requires prolonged doxycycline treatment due to the invasive nature and lymphatic involvement. Single-dose azithromycin is ineffective for LGV but works for uncomplicated Chlamydia infections (D–K).

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with HIV presents with bacillary angiomatosis—vascular, red-purple skin nodules. Biopsy shows Warthin-Starry stain–positive bacilli. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Bartonella henselae causes bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients. It is diagnosed by silver staining (Warthin-Starry) and treated with macrolides. It differs from Kaposi sarcoma in histopathology and etiology.

questions.text: A patient develops fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash beginning on wrists and ankles and spreading centrally. History reveals tick exposure. What is the likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Rickettsia rickettsii causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, characterized by centripetally spreading rash and systemic illness. Diagnosis is clinical; doxycycline is the treatment of choice—even in children.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a painless penile ulcer. VDRL is positive, and FTA-ABS is confirmatory. What is the earliest test that would detect the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Explanation:
In primary syphilis, Treponema pallidum can be visualized by dark-field microscopy from chancre exudate. Serologic tests (non-treponemal like VDRL/RPR and treponemal like FTA-ABS/TPHA) become positive later.

questions.text: A hospitalized patient develops greenish-blue pus from a burn wound. The wound culture grows Gram-negative rods that are oxidase positive and produce a fruity odour. Which pigment is uniquely produced by this organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common nosocomial pathogen known for its pigment production. Pyocyanin gives a characteristic blue-green color and generates reactive oxygen species contributing to tissue damage. It also produces pyoverdin (fluorescent green), but pyocyanin is the pigment giving the classic color and virulence in burn wounds.

questions.text: A veterinarian presents with undulating fever, malaise, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood culture yields Gram-negative coccobacilli requiring extended incubation. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:
Brucella species cause zoonotic infections like brucellosis. Standard agglutination test (SAT) is the most widely used and reliable test. It detects anti-Brucella antibodies. Blood cultures may require prolonged incubation due to the organism's slow growth. Rose Bengal is a screening test, whereas ELISA is used for chronic or complicated cases.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic gastritis undergoes endoscopy and is found to have peptic ulcer. Biopsy reveals curved Gram-negative rods. Which factor produced by this organism allows it to survive in the stomach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Helicobacter pylori survive the acidic environment of the stomach primarily due to urease, which hydrolyzes urea into ammonia, neutralizing gastric acid locally. This adaptation allows colonization of the gastric mucosa and contributes to peptic ulcer formation.

questions.text: A child with diarrhea shows Gram-negative, comma-shaped rods on stool culture. The organism is oxidase-positive and grows at 42°C. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni is a leading cause of bacterial gastroenteritis. It shows darting motility, oxidase positivity, and grows optimally at 42°C (thermophilic). V. cholerae grows best at alkaline pH and doesn’t grow at 42°C.

questions.text: A fisherman presents with rice-water stools and dehydration. Which toxin is responsible for the profuse watery diarrhea in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, an AB5 enterotoxin that activates adenylate cyclase via ADP-ribosylation of Gs protein, increasing cAMP and causing chloride and water efflux in enterocytes—leading to massive watery diarrhea

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child develops epiglottitis with stridor and drooling. Which of the following virulence factors is most important for the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) causes severe pediatric infections including epiglottitis. The poly-ribosyl-phosphate (PRP) capsule is essential for virulence, preventing phagocytosis. This is the basis for the Hib vaccine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic man presents with pneumonia and greenish sputum. Gram stain shows Gram-negative rods, oxidase positive, non-lactose fermenting. Culture has a grape-like odour. Which feature contributes most to its antibiotic resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is intrinsically resistant to many antibiotics due to reduced outer membrane permeability (porin loss), multidrug efflux pumps, and beta-lactamases. These mechanisms make infections notoriously difficult to treat. Biofilms contribute to chronic infections (e.g., CF), but efflux and porins are key for systemic resistance.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents with urethritis. Gram stain of urethral discharge shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci. Which medium is most appropriate for culture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Neisseria gonorrhoeae is fastidious and requires enriched media like Thayer-Martin agar, which contains vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim to inhibit commensals. Chocolate agar supports growth but is not selective.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with infertility has a positive chlamydial NAAT. Which complication results from chronic infection with Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D–K?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Chronic Chlamydia trachomatis infection can lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which may involve perihepatitis—Fitz-Hugh–Curtis syndrome, presenting with right upper quadrant pain and violin-string adhesions between liver and peritoneum.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with dysuria and clear urethral discharge. Gram stain is negative for organisms, but NAAT is positive for Mycoplasma genitalium. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Mycoplasma genitalium lacks a cell wall and is intrinsically resistant to beta-lactams. Azithromycin is the drug of choice, though resistance is rising. Doxycycline is an alternative but less effective.

choices.text: Stimulates mast cells to release histamine.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with severe cough followed by vomiting. The coughing spells worsen at night. What is the role of pertussis toxin in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Pertussis toxin ADP-ribosylates Gi proteins, inhibiting their activity and causing unregulated cAMP production. This affects immune cells and contributes to lymphocytosis and paroxysmal cough. Tracheal cytotoxin, not pertussis toxin, damages epithelium.

questions.text: A 40-year-old traveller to India presents with profuse watery diarrhea. Stool microscopy shows no leukocytes. What distinguishes Vibrio cholerae from enteroinvasive organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:
V. cholerae causes secretory diarrhea by producing enterotoxin without mucosal invasion, so no fecal leukocytes or RBCs are present. In contrast, Shigella or EIEC invade mucosa, causing dysentery.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with unvaccinated status presents with meningitis. H. influenzae type b is suspected. Which test best identifies the capsular antigen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Latex agglutination test detects the capsular polysaccharide antigen of H. influenzae type b in CSF, useful especially when culture is negative (e.g., prior antibiotics). It’s rapid and helps in early diagnosis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man develops endocarditis after dental surgery. Blood culture grows pleomorphic Gram-negative bacilli. Which Haemophilus species is part of the HACEK group responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
The HACEK group (Haemophilus, Aggregatibacter, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) includes Haemophilus parainfluenzae, which can cause culture-negative endocarditis. These fastidious organisms may require enriched media and prolonged incubation.

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the persistent antigenic variation in relapsing fever caused by Borrelia recurrentis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Borrelia recurrentis changes its outer surface proteins, allowing immune evasion and relapsing fever. Each wave of fever corresponds to emergence of a new antigenic variant, escaping prior immunity.

questions.text: A patient with cystic fibrosis has recurrent pulmonary infections with Gram-negative, oxidase-positive rods producing a mucoid colony. Which virulence factor is critical in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
In cystic fibrosis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa forms a mucoid alginate biofilm that protects it from immune response and antibiotics. Chronic colonization contributes to respiratory decline.

questions.text: A 27-year-old hiker presents with arthritis of the knee and Bell’s palsy. Which stage of Lyme disease is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Stage 2 Lyme disease includes neurological (e.g., cranial neuropathies like facial palsy) and migratory arthritis, typically affecting large joints. It follows the initial erythema migrans phase and precedes late persistent disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female develops genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy. Aspirated pus from a bubo reveals Gram-negative inclusions in monocytes. Which stain best identifies the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1–L3). Inclusions in monocytes are best seen on Giemsa stain, which highlights reticulate and elementary bodies inside host cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with HIV presents with seizures and brain mass lesions. Serology for Toxoplasma is negative. Biopsy shows Gram-negative coccobacilli with silver stain positivity. Likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
In immunocompromised patients, Bartonella henselae may cause bacillary angiomatosis with CNS involvement. Silver stain helps differentiate it from fungal and protozoan infections. Brain involvement mimics toxoplasmosis but serology helps differentiate.

questions.text: A newborn has bilateral conjunctivitis 7 days after birth. Gram stain shows no organisms. What is the most likely cause and treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Inclusion conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatis (D–K) occurs 5–14 days postnatally. Gram stain is negative due to its intracellular nature. Oral erythromycin is required to treat both conjunctivitis and potential pneumonia.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with profuse diarrhea. Culture on Campy-BAP agar at 42°C shows curved Gram-negative rods with darting motility. What is the most likely source of infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni is commonly transmitted via undercooked poultry. It grows at 42°C, has darting motility, and can trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome due to molecular mimicry between bacterial LPS and host gangliosides.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with dysuria and a mucopurulent urethral discharge. Gram stain shows no organisms. NAAT confirms Chlamydia trachomatis. Which life cycle form is infectious?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Chlamydia trachomatis has a biphasic life cycle. The elementary body is the small, dense, extracellular, infectious form that enters host cells. Inside, it converts into the reticulate body, which replicates.

questions.text: A patient with a prosthetic joint develops late-onset sepsis. Culture grows oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting Gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following contributes to its persistence on prostheses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa forms biofilms, especially on prosthetic devices and catheters. The mucoid exopolysaccharide alginate facilitates adhesion and antibiotic resistance, making eradication difficult.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a chronic cough and diffuse infiltrates on chest X-ray. Cold agglutinin test is positive. Which feature of the organism explains the failure of Gram stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Explanation:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, hence it does not stain with Gram stain. It has a triple-layered cell membrane rich in sterols. Beta-lactams are ineffective; macrolides or doxycycline are preferred.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with incomplete vaccination presents with severe coughing fits and vomiting. The pathogen grows best on which of the following selective media?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Bordetella pertussis requires enriched media like Regan-Lowe agar (charcoal, horse blood, antibiotics) or Bordet-Gengou agar. These suppress contaminants and support the growth of the fastidious organism.

questions.text: A man with occupational exposure to livestock develops undulating fever, night sweats, and back pain. Which blood culture method is preferred for isolating the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Brucella is slow-growing and requires prolonged incubation. Castaneda medium, a biphasic system (liquid and solid), increases yield in brucellosis, especially in chronic infections. Automated systems may miss slow growers.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man has diarrhea after consuming undercooked chicken. Stool culture reveals curved, motile, oxidase-positive Gram-negative rods. What neurological complication is associated with this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Campylobacter jejuni infection may trigger Guillain-Barré syndrome via molecular mimicry between bacterial lipo-oligosaccharides and peripheral nerve gangliosides. This results in demyelinating polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with PID. Culture is negative. NAAT reveals co-infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. Why are both treated empirically?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Co-infection of gonorrhoea and chlamydia is common, especially in young adults. CDC recommends empiric treatment for both with ceftriaxone + doxycycline, regardless of test availability, to prevent PID and complications.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with fever and flu-like illness after consuming unpasteurized soft cheese. Blood culture grows small, Gram-positive rods with tumbling motility. What is the major virulence factor aiding intracellular survival?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Listeria monocytogenes invades host cells using internalin, escapes the phagosome via listeriolysin O, and moves using actin polymerization. Internalin helps it cross the placental barrier, causing fetal infection.

questions.text: A patient presents with watery diarrhea. Culture on TCBS agar reveals yellow colonies. Which biochemical test confirms the diagnosis of Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
The string test is used to identify Vibrio cholerae. When colonies are mixed with sodium deoxycholate, they lyse and form a viscous "string" of DNA. TCBS agar supports growth and shows sucrose fermentation (yellow colonies).

questions.text: A patient with pneumonia has silver stain–positive intracellular bacilli and hyponatremia. Which is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Legionella pneumophila causes atypical pneumonia with GI symptoms, confusion, and hyponatremia. It stains with silver and grows on BCYE agar with L-cysteine and iron. Often acquired via contaminated water.

questions.text: A 23-year-old with tick exposure presents with fever, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia. No rash is seen. PCR shows Ehrlichia chaffeensis. Which cell type is infected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Ehrlichia chaffeensis infects monocytes, forming morulae (basophilic inclusions). It causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis. Rash is absent in many cases, unlike RMSF. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with mucopurulent cervicitis and lower abdominal pain. Culture is negative, but NAAT confirms Chlamydia trachomatis. Which serious complication can result if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Explanation:
Untreated Chlamydia trachomatis (serovars D–K) can ascend the reproductive tract and cause pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Chronic inflammation and tubal scarring significantly increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy and infertility.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with high fever, malaise, and hepatosplenomegaly. He had contact with feral pigs while hunting. Blood culture grows slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacilli. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Brucella suis is associated with feral pigs and hunters. It causes brucellosis, a systemic zoonosis with undulant fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and arthritis. Diagnosis requires prolonged culture or serologic testing.

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever and severe sore throat. Rapid strep test is negative. Cold agglutinin test is positive, and chest X-ray shows interstitial infiltrates. Likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes atypical pneumonia, especially in teenagers and young adults. Positive cold agglutinin test (autoimmune hemolysis) is characteristic. It causes dry cough and patchy X-ray infiltrates.

questions.text: A child with watery diarrhea is found to have infection with Vibrio cholerae. Which mechanism explains the massive fluid loss in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ADP-ribosylation of Gs → ↑ cAMP
Explanation:
Cholera toxin ADP-ribosylates the Gs subunit, activating adenylate cyclase, which increases cAMP, leading to chloride and water secretion into the gut lumen → rice-water diarrhea.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with a genital ulcer. Dark-field microscopy reveals tightly coiled, motile spirochetes. He is allergic to penicillin. What is the alternative treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
For primary syphilis, benzathine penicillin G is first line. If the patient is allergic to penicillin and not pregnant, doxycycline is the best alternative. Penicillin desensitization is preferred during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a necrotic skin ulcer after skinning rabbits. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Francisella tularensis, a zoonotic agent acquired from rabbits, causes ulcero-glandular tularaemia. It is highly infectious, requiring only a few organisms for infection. Diagnosis requires serology or PCR.

questions.text: A patient presents with painless genital ulcer and generalized lymphadenopathy. VDRL and FTA-ABS are both positive. Which stage of syphilis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation:
The hallmark of primary syphilis is a painless chancre. Serologic tests (VDRL, FTA-ABS) may be positive by the end of this stage. Lymphadenopathy is typically regional and non-tender. Secondary stage presents with a systemic rash.

choices.text: It belongs to Biosafety Level 4 pathogens
It is unlikely to infect humans.

questions.text: A laboratory technician handling a clinical specimen containing an unknown virus is advised to use a Class III biosafety cabinet. What does this suggest about the suspected virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It belongs to Biosafety Level 4 pathogens.
Explanation:
Class III biosafety cabinets are used for working with BSL-4 pathogens, which are high-risk agents such as Ebola, Marburg, or Lassa viruses. These viruses are highly infectious, have no effective treatment or vaccine, and require maximum containment. Biosafety level is based on pathogenicity, transmissibility, and risk to lab personnel and the public—not viral structure alone.

questions.text: Which of the following is a defining feature of all RNA viruses except orthomyxoviruses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Replicate in the cytoplasm
Explanation:
Most RNA viruses replicate in the cytoplasm, unlike orthomyxoviruses (e.g., influenza), which replicate in the nucleus. Exceptions help with unique features like splicing of mRNA. Other properties like symmetry and envelope status vary widely.

questions.text: Which virus contains reverse transcriptase but does not integrate into the host genome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hepatitis B virus
Explanation:
HBV is a DNA virus with reverse transcriptase activity. It replicates via an RNA intermediate, but unlike retroviruses, its genome does not obligatorily integrate into the host genome for replication. Integration can occur in chronic cases and is linked to hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is a viral structural protein that is typically involved in host cell receptor binding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Envelope glycoprotein
Explanation:
Envelope glycoproteins mediate attachment to specific host cell receptors, determining viral tropism. Capsid proteins can bind in non-enveloped viruses. Polymerases are internal, and teguments are herpesvirus-specific matrix proteins.

questions.text: A virus with a segmented RNA genome is capable of antigenic shift. Which of the following viruses shares this feature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Influenza virus
Explanation:
Antigenic shift involves genetic reassortment and occurs in viruses with segmented genomes, like influenza (8 RNA segments). This leads to major pandemics. Measles, rabies, and dengue are non-segmented and undergo antigenic drift, not shift.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses is most likely to be reactivated in an immunocompromised patient after bone marrow transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cytomegalovirus
Explanation:
CMV is a herpesvirus that establishes latency in mononuclear cells. It can reactivate in immunocompromised hosts, especially post-transplant, causing pneumonia, retinitis, or colitis. Rhinovirus and norovirus do not establish latency; rotavirus causes acute GI infection.

questions.text: Which structural protein of SARS-CoV-2 binds directly to the host ACE2 receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Spike (S) protein
Explanation:
The Spike protein (S) mediates receptor binding and fusion, making it a major target for vaccines and neutralizing antibodies.

choices.text: RT-PCR from throat swab or CSF

questions.text: What is the recommended diagnostic modality for early confirmation of Nipah virus infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

RT-PCR from throat swab or CSF
Explanation:
RT-PCR is the method of choice to detect Nipah viral RNA early. ELISA may confirm exposure, but RT-PCR offers faster and direct detection.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main reservoir of Hantavirus in the wild?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Deer mice
Explanation:
Hantavirus is harboured by rodents (especially deer mice). Humans become infected by inhaling aerosolized rodent urine or droppings. It is not spread by bats or ticks.

choices.text: Skin biopsy from nape of neck

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a bat bite develops confusion, hydrophobia, and photophobia. Which of the following is the earliest and most reliable specimen for rabies virus detection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Skin biopsy from nape of neck
Explanation:
The nape of the neck skin biopsy contains hair follicles innervated by peripheral nerves, allowing early detection of rabies virus antigen via direct fluorescent antibody testing. Saliva may contain virus intermittently. CSF is nonspecific.

questions.text: What is the role of rabies virus glycoprotein G?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Antigenicity and host receptor binding
Explanation:
Rabies glycoprotein G mediates attachment to host receptors (e.g., acetylcholine receptor) and determines antigenicity. Neuronal transport is via dynein motors on microtubules, not directly by G protein.

choices.text: It is a linear double-stranded DNA virus
It consists of multiple negative-sense RNA segments

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the genetic structure of influenza viruses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 It consists of multiple negative-sense RNA segments.
Explanation:
Influenza viruses have segmented (8 segments) of negative sense ssRNA, enabling reassortment (antigenic shift). It replicates in the nucleus, an exception among RNA viruses. It is not a DNA virus.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of paralysis in poliomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Destruction of anterior horn cells
Explanation:
Poliovirus infects and destroys anterior horn cells of the spinal cord, leading to lower motor neuron-type paralysis. It does not affect the dorsal root ganglia or peripheral myelin.

questions.text: A patient develops transient aplastic crisis after parvovirus B19 infection. Which of the following conditions predisposes to this complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hereditary spherocytosis
Explanation:
Parvovirus B19 infects erythroid precursors in bone marrow, causing transient aplastic crisis in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis). It has tropism for P antigen on RBCs.

questions.text: A child born to an HIV-positive mother tests negative for HIV at birth. Which test should be used to confirm the infection status in the first few months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV-1 DNA PCR
Explanation:
In neonates, maternal IgG antibodies can persist and give false positives on ELISA or Western blot. HIV-1 DNA PCR is preferred for early infant diagnosis. CD4 count doesn’t establish infection status.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a vesicular rash over the left thorax in a dermatomal pattern. Which virus is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

VZV
Explanation:
Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) causes chickenpox in primary infection and shingles (herpes zoster) upon reactivation, commonly in immunocompromised or elderly patients. Dermatomal vesicles are typical. HSV causes localized genital/oral lesions; CMV usually doesn't cause vesicles.

questions.text: Which of the following herpesviruses is associated with Kaposi's sarcoma in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 HHV-8
Explanation:
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is associated with Kaposi’s sarcoma, particularly in AIDS patients. It promotes angiogenesis and spindle cell proliferation. HHV-6 causes roseola. HSV-1/2 cause mucocutaneous lesions, not vascular tumors.

questions.text: A patient with a bone marrow transplant develops interstitial pneumonia. Biopsy shows "owl eye" inclusions. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
CMV
Explanation:
Cytomegalovirus is a common cause of pneumonitis in post-transplant patients. Histopathology reveals large cells with basophilic nuclear inclusions ("owl eye" appearance). EBV is associated with lymphomas. HSV and VZV don’t show owl eye inclusions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B has serology showing HBsAg+, HBeAg–, and anti-HBe+. His HBV DNA levels are high. What mutation is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Pre-core mutant
Explanation:
Pre-core mutants are HBeAg-negative but still replicate actively, hence high HBV DNA. These variants cannot produce HBeAg due to mutations in the pre-core region. They are common in Asia and the Mediterranean and associated with progressive liver disease.

choices.text: There is a highly effective vaccine available
Reinfection is rare after successful treatment
It is a double-stranded RNA virus
It shows a high degree of genetic variability

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Hepatitis C virus is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 It shows a high degree of genetic variability.
Explanation:
HCV is a single-stranded RNA virus with extensive genetic variability, especially in the E2 glycoprotein region, which complicates vaccine development. Reinfection can occur even after treatment. There is no vaccine.

choices.text: Superinfection with HDV on chronic HBV

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with chronic hepatitis D infection shows presence of HBsAg but absence of HBcAg. What does this imply?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Superinfection with HDV on chronic HBV
Explanation:
Superinfection refers to HDV infecting someone already chronically infected with HBV. HBsAg is needed for HDV envelope formation. Superinfection is more severe than co-infection and often leads to fulminant hepatitis or cirrhosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective strategy for eradication of poliovirus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Use of oral polio vaccine (OPV)
Explanation:
OPV induces mucosal immunity (IgA), preventing viral replication and transmission. It also spreads to close contacts. However, vaccine-derived polio is a risk. IPV induces good systemic immunity but limited gut immunity.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with vesicular lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa, along with maculopapular rash on palms and soles. Which is the most likely virus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Coxsackievirus A16
Explanation:
This presentation is classic for hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus A16, a member of Picornaviridae. It’s self-limiting. HSV causes painful grouped vesicles; VZV is more widespread; measles doesn’t present with vesicles.

questions.text: A young adult presents with acute chest pain, elevated cardiac enzymes, and ECG changes. PCR of endomyocardial tissue shows viral RNA. Which virus is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Coxsackievirus B
Explanation:
Coxsackievirus B is a leading viral cause of myocarditis and pericarditis, especially in young adults. It directly infects cardiomyocytes. Adenovirus and CMV can also cause myocarditis but are less common. EBV primarily affects lymphoid tissue.

questions.text: Ebola virus exhibits which of the following structural features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 Helical, enveloped, negative sense ssRNA
Explanation:
Ebola virus is a filovirus: enveloped, helical-shaped, and negative-sense ssRNA. Its filamentous structure is characteristic. It causes severe viral hemorrhagic fever with high fatality.

questions.text: Which virus family uses reverse transcription but is not a retrovirus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepadnaviridae
Explanation:
Hepatitis B (Hepadnaviridae) is a DNA virus using reverse transcription during replication but is not a retrovirus.

questions.text: Which viral encephalitis shows predilection for temporal lobes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HSV-1
Explanation:
HHV1 encephalitis shows predilection for Temporal lobe.  HHV meningitis is named as Mollaret meningitis.

questions.text: The most effective way to prevent HPV-related cancers is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vaccination before sexual debut
Explanation:
Effective vaccination against HPV before sexual debut is the best method to prevent HPV related cancers.

questions.text: A 4yearold child presents with a high fever followed by the appearance of a rash that starts on the face and spreads to the trunk. Koplik spots are observed in the oral cavity. Which virus is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Measles virus
Explanation: 
Measles virus causes a characteristic prodrome of high fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, followed by a maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads to the trunk.

questions.text: A 25yearold pregnant woman presents with fever, joint pain, and a rash. She is found to have Zika virus infection. Which of the following complications is most concerning for the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Microcephaly
Explanation: 
Zika virus infection during pregnancy is associated with a significant risk of fetal microcephaly and other congenital abnormalities.

questions.text: A barefoot farmer presents with iron-deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy reveals segmented eggs. What is the most likely route of infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus (hookworms) cause iron-deficiency anemia due to blood loss from intestinal capillaries. Infection occurs via skin penetration by filariform larvae, often through bare feet. Eggs are oval with a thin shell and segmented ovum inside.

questions.text: A child from an endemic area presents with diarrhea and stunted growth. Microscopy reveals bile-stained, mamillated eggs. Which complication is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are mamillated and bile stained. The adult worms can migrate into the biliary tree, causing biliary obstruction, pancreatitis, or cholangitis. Children with heavy loads may also experience growth retardation and intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A woman presents with frothy vaginal discharge and vaginal itching. Wet mount of vaginal fluid shows motile flagellated organisms. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan that causes frothy, greenish-yellow vaginal discharge, vaginal irritation, and a “strawberry cervix.” Diagnosis is by wet mount, showing motile trophozoites. Metronidazole is the drug of choice, and sexual partners must also be treated.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly enlarging cyst in the liver. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed lesion with daughter cysts. Which feature on aspiration confirms hydatid disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Echinococcus granulosus causes hydatid cysts, usually in the liver. On aspiration, presence of hydatid sand (free hook lets and protoscolices) confirms diagnosis. Aspiration must be done cautiously due to risk of anaphylaxis. Dogs are definitive hosts.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy in a malaria-endemic area has recurrent malaria episodes with dormant hepatic stages. Which species is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
P. vivax and P. ovale form hypnozoites—dormant liver stages that can reactivate and cause relapsing malaria. Treatment requires both chloroquine (blood schizonticide) and primaquine (to kill hypnozoites). G6PD testing is needed before giving primaquine.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man develops chronic lymphatic obstruction and scrotal swelling after years in a filariasis-endemic region. What is the vector for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Explanation:
Wuchereria bancrofti, transmitted by Culex mosquitoes, causes lymphatic filariasis, leading to elephantiasis. Adult worms lodge in lymphatics, causing obstruction and lymphatic damage. Diagnosis is by detection of microfilariae in night-time blood samples.

questions.text: A young girl presents with itching and skin nodules over the legs. She is from a village near a fast-flowing river in Africa. Skin snip shows microfilariae. Likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Onchocerca volvulus causes river blindness. Transmitted by Simulium (blackfly), it causes subcutaneous nodules, pruritus, and microfilariae in skin and eyes, leading to blindness. Diagnosis is by skin snip and Mazzotti reaction (response to ivermectin).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with intermittent diarrhea. Ova in stool have a large operculum and are bile stained. He admits to eating undercooked freshwater crab. Which parasite is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Paragonimus westermani is the lung fluke, but its eggs are found in sputum or stool. Infections follow ingestion of undercooked crabs or crayfish. Eggs are operculated, bile-stained, and diagnosis is via sputum/stool microscopy. It may mimic TB due to hemoptysis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child from a tropical country presents with foul-smelling diarrhea. Stool wet mount shows oocysts that auto fluoresce under UV light. Which parasite is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation:
Cyclospora cayetanensis causes prolonged watery diarrhea in children and travellers. Oocysts are acid-fast and show autofluorescence under UV light. It’s transmitted via contaminated water or food, especially imported produce.

questions.text: A man presents with chronic eosinophilia and GI symptoms. Stool examination shows larvae, not eggs. Which test confirms the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Explanation:
Strongyloides stercoralis causes autoinfection and disseminated disease in immunocompromised patients. Diagnosis is by detecting rhabditiform larvae (not eggs) in stool. Baermann technique concentrates larvae by exploiting their motility.

choices.text: Repeat testing for ova in 2 weeks

questions.text: A child presents with perianal itching. The mother applied transparent tape to the perianal region in the morning, and microscopy shows eggs. What is the most appropriate follow-up step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Enterobius vermicularis is highly contagious. After diagnosis by scotch tape test, treatment of the patient and household contacts is essential. Mebendazole or albendazole is given, followed by repeat dosing after 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with haematuria and dysuria. Cystoscopy shows bladder wall fibrosis. Urine microscopy reveals eggs with a terminal spine. What long-term complication is associated with this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Schistosoma haematobium infection leads to chronic bladder inflammation and has a strong association with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Eggs with terminal spines are diagnostic in urine.

questions.text: A traveller returns from South America with fever, swollen eyelid (Romaña sign), and cardiomegaly. Which stage of the organism is detected in blood during acute illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Explanation:
Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease. The trypomastigote is found in peripheral blood during acute illness. Chronic infection leads to cardiomyopathy, megacolon, and megaoesophagus. The vector is the reduviid bug.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child in a daycare develops greasy, foul-smelling stools and weight loss. Stool antigen test is positive. What is the best treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Giardia lamblia causes malabsorption syndrome with steatorrhea. It’s common in daycare settings due to fecal-oral transmission. Metronidazole is the first-line treatment, though tinidazole and nitazoxanide are alternatives.

questions.text: A boy from Africa develops seizures and hydrocephalus. CSF shows motile flagellated organisms. What is the likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Naegleria fowleri causes primary amoebic meningoencephalitis, usually contracted from swimming in warm freshwater. Trophozoites are found in CSF, and disease is rapidly fatal. Treated experimentally with amphotericin B.

questions.text: A child from a rural area presents with rectal prolapse and iron-deficiency anemia. Stool microscopy shows barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs. Which parasite is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:

Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) causes rectal prolapse, dysentery, and anemia. Its eggs are barrel shaped with bipolar plugs, and heavy infection affects the rectal mucosa in children.

questions.text: A woman presents with recurrent seizures. CT scan shows multiple calcified brain lesions. Which test confirms the parasitic cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Neurocysticercosis due to Taenia solium presents with seizures and calcified brain cysts. Serology (ELISA or Western blot) confirms the diagnosis. Stool O&P helps identify adult worm shedding but not CNS disease.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman returns from a village with fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and mild jaundice. Blood smear shows ring-shaped parasites inside RBCs with occasional multiple infections per cell. What is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Plasmodium falciparum is the most virulent malaria species and shows multiple ring forms per RBC and no Schüffner's dots. It can cause severe complications, including cerebral malaria and renal failure. The banana-shaped gametocytes are also characteristic.

questions.text: A young adult with a history of eating raw freshwater fish develops obstructive jaundice. Imaging shows biliary tract dilatation. Which parasite is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke) infects the biliary tract and is acquired by eating undercooked fish. It can lead to cholangitis, biliary obstruction, and cholangiocarcinoma. Eggs are operculated and appear in stool.

questions.text: A man is admitted with fever, chills, hemolytic anemia, and jaundice. He recently returned from the northeastern U.S. and had a tick bite. Blood smear shows tetrads in RBCs (Maltese cross). What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation:
Babesia microti causes hemolytic anemia and is transmitted by Ixodes ticks, like Borrelia. It is characterized by Maltese cross tetrads on peripheral smear. It affects asplenic or immunocompromised individuals more severely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has haematuria and is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. He lived in Egypt for several years. What is the most likely parasitic cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Explanation:
Schistosoma haematobium is endemic in parts of Africa and the Middle East. Chronic infection causes bladder inflammation, fibrosis, and predisposes to squamous cell carcinoma. Eggs are seen in urine with a terminal spine.

questions.text: A girl has seizures. CT scan shows a single ring-enhancing lesion. She owns pigs and consumes pork regularly. Which diagnostic test is most sensitive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation:
Serology is the most sensitive and specific test for neurocysticercosis, especially when imaging is inconclusive. MRI/CT can show cysts or calcifications, but ELISA confirms the parasitic etiology.

questions.text: A child from an endemic area presents with massive splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and hyperpigmented skin ("black sickness"). Bone marrow biopsy shows amastigotes. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) caused by Leishmania donovani presents with fever, splenomegaly, pancytopenia, and hyperpigmentation. Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice. Alternatives include miltefosine and sodium stibogluconate.

questions.text: A man returns from Brazil with skin ulcers, mucosal erosion, and enlarged lymph nodes. Microscopy of a biopsy shows amastigotes. What is the likely species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Leishmania brasiliensis causes mucocutaneous leishmaniasis in South America. The disease begins with a skin ulcer, then progresses to destruction of nasal/oral mucosa. Amastigotes are seen in macrophages.

questions.text: A 12-year-old presents with abdominal discomfort and visible motile worms in stool. Stool shows bile-stained, round, corticated eggs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are round, bile-stained, and mamillated. Adult worms may be passed in stool. Heavy infestations cause intestinal obstruction or biliary complications.

questions.text: A fisherman from Southeast Asia has mild jaundice and abdominal pain. Stool exam shows operculated eggs. What is the chronic complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, infects biliary ducts and causes cholangitis, stones, and cholangiocarcinoma. The operculated eggs are diagnostic on stool exam. Transmitted via undercooked fish.

questions.text: A child presents with anemia and abdominal pain. He has a history of playing barefoot. Stool microscopy shows eggs with thin shells and segmented ovum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) causes iron-deficiency anemia by sucking blood from intestinal mucosa. Infection occurs via skin penetration, and eggs are thin-shelled, non-bile-stained, and contain segmented ovum.

questions.text: A patient develops respiratory distress, urticaria, and GI symptoms after starting steroids for asthma. Larvae are seen in sputum and stool. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Strongyloides can cause hyper infection syndrome in immunosuppressed patients. Larvae disseminate through the lungs and gut, causing respiratory failure, enterocolitis, and septicaemia. Sputum and stool may show larvae.

questions.text: A patient develops progressive fatigue and pallor. He admits to eating raw freshwater fish. Stool shows operculated eggs. Labs reveal low vitamin B12. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Diphyllobothrium latum is the fish tapeworm that competes for vitamin B12, causing megaloblastic anemia. The eggs are operculated, and ingestion of undercooked fish is the source.

questions.text: A child presents with abdominal discomfort and anal itching. Perianal tape prep reveals flattened-side eggs. What is the most common complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation:
Enterobius vermicularis has been associated with appendicitis, although rarely. The eggs are flattened on one side and found using cellophane tape prep.

questions.text: A patient has diarrhea and microscopic stool exam reveals teardrop-shaped trophozoites with two nuclei and four flagella. Which of the following contributes most to its pathogenicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation:
Giardia lamblia adheres to the intestinal wall via a ventral sucking disc, leading to villous atrophy and malabsorption. It doesn’t invade mucosa, so no blood or leukocytes in stool are typically seen.

questions.text: A woman in late pregnancy is found to be IgM positive for Toxoplasma gondii. What fetal abnormality is most likely if vertical transmission occurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Congenital toxoplasmosis may cause chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. IgM positivity indicates recent infection, and first-trimester infection is most severe.

questions.text: A man presents with weight loss and abdominal discomfort. He frequently eats raw beef. Which parasite is likely and how is it differentiated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Explanation:
Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) is identified by absence of hooks on scolex and more uterine branches in proglottids. It causes mild symptoms and is transmitted by raw beef.

questions.text: A 40yearold man presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain. Stool examination reveals oval cysts with four nuclei. Which organism is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Entamoeba histolytica
Explanation: 
Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery and is identified by the presence of cysts with four nuclei in stool samples.

questions.text: Which of the following is the definitive host for Toxoplasma gondii?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
Cats are the definitive host. They excrete oocysts in feces. Humans and other animals are intermediate hosts.

questions.text: The infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
Promastigote is the flagellated form found in sandfly, and it infects humans during the sandfly bite.

questions.text: Kala-azar is diagnosed serologically using which of the following tests?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation: 
rK39 is a rapid immunochromatographic test detecting antibodies against Leishmania donovani.

questions.text: The ‘nurse cell’ formation is a hallmark of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Explanation: 
T. spiralis larvae encyst in skeletal muscle forming nurse cells.

questions.text: Which parasite causes 'Winterbottom sign'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: 
Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy in African sleeping sickness is known as Winterbottom sign.

questions.text: A patient has subcutaneous swellings and migratory skin lesions. Calabar swellings are associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Explanation: 
Loa loa causes Calabar swellings due to localized angioedema.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with a verrucous skin lesion over the leg. Histopathology shows brown-pigmented “sclerotic bodies” or “copper pennies.” Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Chromoblastomycosis
Explanation:
Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic subcutaneous infection by pigmented fungi like Fonsecaea pedrosoi, with hallmark sclerotic bodies (“copper penny” cells) seen in tissue. Lesions are verrucous and slow growing.

questions.text: Which dermatophyte infects only skin and nails, but not hair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Epidermophyton floccosum
Explanation:
E. floccosum infects skin and nails, but not hair. Trichophyton affects all three (skin, hair, nails). Microsporum infects skin and hair, not nails.

questions.text: Which test is useful for the rapid diagnosis of tinea infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

KOH mount
Explanation:
KOH preparation digests keratin and reveals fungal hyphae in skin scrapings. It’s the first-line diagnostic method in dermatophytosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, weight loss, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy reveals small intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Histoplasma capsulatum
Explanation:
Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus endemic to Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. It causes pulmonary and disseminated disease, especially in immunocompromised hosts. Histology shows small intracellular yeast in macrophages.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from Arizona develops cough, fever, and chest pain. Biopsy reveals large spherules filled with endospores. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Coccidioidomycosis
Explanation:
Coccidioides immitis is endemic in Southwestern USA (deserts). It is dimorphic and produces spherules with endospores in tissues (not yeast). Known as "Valley fever", it can disseminate to bones, skin, or CNS.

questions.text: A South American farmer presents with chronic mucocutaneous ulcers and lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows “pilot wheel” yeast forms. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
Explanation:
Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes South American blastomycosis. Histology reveals large yeast with multiple budding in "pilot wheel" or "Mickey mouse" arrangement. It commonly affects oral mucosa and lymph nodes.

choices.text: They grow as yeast in the environment
They are mold in cold and yeast in heat.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dimorphic fungi is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

They are mold in cold and yeast in heat.
Explanation:
Dimorphic fungi exhibit thermal dimorphism: mold form at 25°C (environment), and yeast form at 37°C (tissue). A classic mnemonic is “mold in the cold, yeast in the heat.”

questions.text: A forestry worker presents with ulcerated skin lesions, productive cough, and lung nodules. Sputum culture grows broad-based budding yeast. What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blastomyces dermatitidis
Explanation:
Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus with broad-based budding yeast in tissue. It can cause pulmonary, cutaneous, or disseminated infection, often in the Great Lakes and Mississippi basin areas.

questions.text: Talaromyces (Penicillium) marneffei causes disseminated infection primarily in which group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HIV-infected individuals in Southeast Asia
Explanation:
Talaromyces marneffei (formerly Penicillium marneffei) is endemic in Southeast Asia and causes disseminated infection in AIDS patients. It is a dimorphic fungus and produces red pigment on culture.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi is associated with caves and bat droppings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Histoplasma capsulatum
Explanation:
Histoplasma thrives in soil enriched with bird or bat guano, especially in caves. Infection occurs via inhalation of microconidia.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates Candida albicans from non-albicans Candida species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Germ tube test
Explanation:
Germ tube test is positive in C. albicans and negative in most other Candida species. It involves serum incubation and reveals germ tube formation within 2–3 hours.

questions.text: What is the natural reservoir for Cryptococcus neoformans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pigeon droppings
Explanation:
Cryptococcus neoformans is found in pigeon excreta and soil contaminated with it. Infection occurs via inhalation. Notably, C. gattii is more associated with eucalyptus trees.

questions.text: Which virulence factor is primarily responsible for the pathogenicity of Cryptococcus neoformans?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Capsule
Explanation:
Polysaccharide capsule is the major virulence factor of Cryptococcus, enabling immune evasion. It also inhibits phagocytosis. Melanin contributes to oxidative stress resistance.

questions.text: A patient with asthma develops worsening wheezing and brownish sputum. Labs reveal high IgE and eosinophilia. Sputum culture shows Aspergillus. Likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)
Explanation:
ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus, common in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis. It features IgE elevation, eosinophilia, bronchiectasis, and brownish mucus plugs.

questions.text: Which antifungal is first line for treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Voriconazole
Explanation:
Voriconazole is the drug of choice for invasive aspergillosis. Amphotericin B is an alternative. Fluconazole has poor activity against Aspergillus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with IUD develops chronic pelvic pain. Endometrial biopsy shows budding yeast and pseudohyphae. Most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Candida albicans
Explanation:
Candida albicans may cause chronic endometritis in IUD users. Biopsy shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms. It’s part of normal vaginal flora but pathogenic in certain settings.

questions.text: Which fungus can cause catheter-related fungemia and forms biofilms that are resistant to antifungals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Candida auris
Explanation:
C. auris is an emerging, MDR yeast with high biofilm-forming ability on catheters. It is resistant to multiple antifungals and hard to eradicate from hospital settings.

choices.text: Yeast form in tissue, hyphal form in culture
Spherule in tissue, yeast in culture

questions.text: Which of the following best characterizes Sporothrix schenckii in tissue and culture respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Explanation:
Sporothrix schenckii is dimorphic:
• Yeast form (cigar-shaped) in human tissue (at 37°C)
• Hyphal form with conidia ("floweret") in culture at 25°C
This dimorphism is important in diagnosis.

choices.text: It is lipophilic and requires fatty acids for growth
Shows “spaghetti and meatballs” appearance in KOH mount
It causes hypo- or hyperpigmented macules
It is dimorphic and invasive in immunocompetent hosts.

questions.text: All are true regarding Malassezia furfur EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Explanation:
• Malassezia furfur is not invasive in immunocompetent hosts.
• It causes superficial infection (Tinea versicolor).
• (A) is true – requires lipids → grows on olive oil-enriched SDA.
• (B) is classic microscopic appearance.
• (C) explains clinical presentation.
• (D) is false—it is not dimorphic nor typically invasive.

choices.text: It shows narrow angle branching and septate hyphae
It is commonly isolated on Sabouraud's agar as black pigmented colony
It invades via angioinvasion leading to tissue necrosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic male presents with facial pain, orbital swelling, black nasal discharge, and cranial nerve palsies. KOH mount of nasal swab shows broad, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphae. Which of the following is most accurate regarding the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Explanation:
Mucormycosis (caused by Rhizopus, Mucor) shows broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching.
• The hallmark is angioinvasion → thrombosis → necrosis → black eschar.
• Treatment: IV Amphotericin B + debridement.
• (A) is false—it refers to Aspergillus.
• (B) is incorrect—Rhizopus colonies are cottony white to grey.
• (D) is incorrect—Amphotericin B is first-line.
